title: 107_hr1694
content: REPEAL OF 1993 INCREASES IN HIGHWAY MOTOR FUEL TAXES. The text chunk discusses amendments to the tax rates for highway gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It also includes technical amendments related to the rates of tax. Amendments were made to tax rates for highway gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This included changes to specific clauses and subsections, such as reducing the tax rate from 7.3 cents to 3 cents and eliminating the tax rate of 4.3 cents per gallon. Amendments were made to tax rates for various fuels under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This included changes to specific clauses and subsections, such as reducing the tax rate for liquefied petroleum gas and liquefied natural gas. Additionally, a tax of 0.1 cent per gallon was imposed on diesel fuel used in trains. Amendments were made to tax rates for various fuels under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This included changes to specific clauses and subsections, such as reducing the tax rate for liquefied petroleum gas and liquefied natural gas. Additionally, a tax of 0.1 cent per gallon was imposed on diesel fuel used in trains. Clauses and subsections were amended to adjust tax rates on liquid fuels. Amendments were made to tax rates for various fuels under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including changes to specific clauses and subsections. This involved reducing the tax rate for liquefied petroleum gas and liquefied natural gas, as well as imposing a 0.1 cent per gallon tax on diesel fuel used in trains. Clauses and subsections were adjusted to modify tax rates on liquid fuels. Amendments to tax rates for various fuels under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 were made, including reducing the tax rate for certain fuels and imposing a tax on diesel fuel used in trains. The amendments also included changes to specific clauses and subsections, with an effective date set for the enactment of the Act. Floor Stock Refunds allow for a credit or refund of excess tax paid on liquid held by a dealer before the enactment of the Act, if the liquid is intended for sale and not used. Claims must be filed with the Secretary of the Treasury. The Floor Stock Refunds provision allows for a credit or refund of excess tax paid on liquid held by a dealer before the Act's enactment, provided certain conditions are met. No credit or refund is allowed for liquid held in retail stocks intended for retail sale. The terms "dealer" and "held by a dealer" are defined in section 6412 of the Code. Rules similar to those in section 6412 apply for this provision.
